claim_text: North Dakota has a population of approximately 780,000
North Dakota ranks 47th among U.S. states in population
North Dakota receives just 0.17% of national international migration flows
North Dakota's 0.17% share of international migration is noticeably smaller than its 0.23% share of the U.S. population
Natural population growth has stagnated in North Dakota
Domestic out-migration persists in North Dakota
International migration has emerged as a critical—and at times dominant—component of population change in North Dakota
The Great Plains has experienced sustained population decline throughout much of the twentieth and early twenty-first centuries
The Great Plains demographic trajectory was shaped by agricultural consolidation, limited economic diversification, and the magnetic pull of metropolitan opportunity elsewhere
North Dakota briefly reversed the population decline trend during the Bakken oil boom (2010–2014)
Economic shocks can temporarily reshape demographic patterns, as demonstrated by the Bakken oil boom
The underlying structural forces favoring out-migration in North Dakota have proven resilient despite the oil boom reversal
International migration—particularly refugee resettlement—has assumed an outsized role in maintaining population levels and meeting labor force demands in North Dakota communities
Refugee resettlement programs have channeled arrivals from conflict zones worldwide to North Dakota communities
Refugee resettlement has created ethnic enclaves in North Dakota that now span generations
Location Quotient analysis reveals that North Dakota hosts disproportionately large shares of migrants from East African origins (Somalia, Sudan, Ethiopia)
Concentrations of refugees from Middle Eastern countries (Iraq, Syria) in small states are products of federal resettlement policy interacting with local voluntary agency capacity
Diaspora networks created by refugee resettlement are predictive of subsequent migration streams
Small states like North Dakota have a migration profile markedly different from gateway states, characterized by humanitarian flows rather than economic migration chains
The empirical literature on state-level migration forecasting remains surprisingly thin despite the demographic significance of international migration to small states
The dominant paradigm in migration forecasting focuses on national-level flows, employing gravity models and time series methods calibrated to large-sample settings

When subnational migration analysis appears in the literature, it typically examines major receiving states—California, Texas, Florida, New York—where sample sizes support conventional inferential approaches

Small states, characterized by volatile flows, limited historical observations, and heightened sensitivity to policy shocks, have largely escaped systematic empirical scrutiny in migration forecasting
The gap in small-state migration research reflects genuine methodological challenges
International migration to North Dakota exhibits a coefficient of variation of 82.5%
North Dakota's annual international migration flows have ranged from 30 to over 3,000 net migrants annually over the past fifteen years
Time series of this brevity strain the asymptotic foundations of standard econometric procedures
With short time series, unit root tests lose power, confidence intervals widen dramatically, and structural break detection becomes unreliable
Conventional forecasting approaches may produce misleadingly precise point estimates that obscure the genuine uncertainty surrounding future migration levels
This study uses a multi-method analytical framework that explicitly acknowledges the limitations of small-sample inference while extracting whatever reliable signal the data can support

The analysis triangulates across nine complementary analytical modules: descriptive statistics, time series methods, panel regression, gravity-inspired models, machine learning approaches, causal inference methods, and duration analysis
Where individual methods reach inferential limits, the convergence or divergence of findings across approaches provides additional diagnostic information
The research addresses three interrelated questions

The first research question asks what are the empirical regularities characterizing North Dakota's international migration stream—its level, trend, volatility, composition, and sensitivity to policy interventions
The second research question asks which analytical approaches provide useful leverage for understanding migration dynamics in this small-sample context, and where do conventional methods fail

The third research question asks what range of future migration scenarios is consistent with historical patterns and current policy configurations, and how should forecast uncertainty be characterized and communicated
The analysis provides the first comprehensive multi-method empirical analysis of international migration to a small U.S. state
Rigorous demographic analysis remains feasible even when small populations and short time series strain conventional asymptotic methods
The study applies causal inference methods—difference-in-differences estimation, synthetic control comparators, and instrumental variables analysis—to state-level migration policy evaluation
These causal inference techniques are typically reserved for national-level or cross-country analysis
The research develops a framework for characterizing forecast uncertainty that distinguishes parametric uncertainty from scenario uncertainty
Parametric uncertainty refers to imprecision in estimated relationships
Scenario uncertainty refers to unknowable future policy configurations
The small-sample challenges are not merely technical inconveniences but reflect fundamental limits on what demographic analysis can reliably determine from limited data
This study does not claim to have resolved the small-sample challenges; rather, it attempts to work within them honestly, reporting findings with appropriate uncertainty bounds
The multi-method approach helps identify which findings are robust across analytical frameworks and which depend critically on specific modeling choices
The goal is inference quality over quantity: fewer confident conclusions rather than many dubious ones
This analysis focuses exclusively on international migration—the flow of persons from foreign countries to North Dakota
The analysis does not address domestic migration between U.S. states
Domestic migration represents a larger component of North Dakota's total migration than international migration
Domestic migration operates through different mechanisms and responds to different policy levers than international migration
International and domestic migration may partially substitute or complement each other
Policies affecting one migration stream may have spillover effects on the other
Future work integrating both international and domestic migration components would provide a more complete picture of North Dakota's demographic dynamics
Forecasts are not predictions

The scenario projections represent conditional statements: if policy configurations remain within specified bounds and historical patterns continue, then migration flows are likely to fall within certain ranges
Changes in federal refugee policy could produce outcomes outside the projected intervals
Shifts in global conflict patterns could produce outcomes outside the projected intervals
Economic transformations in North Dakota could produce outcomes outside the projected intervals
The goal of the scenario projections is not to predict the future but to characterize the uncertainty surrounding it
International migration to small U.S. states is characterized by high volatility, limited sample sizes, and heightened sensitivity to federal policy changes.
The demographic literature has extensively examined migration to gateway states.
Small peripheral states have received comparatively little rigorous empirical attention in migration research.
In small peripheral states, migration often determines whether populations grow or decline.
This study is the first comprehensive multi-method analysis of international migration to North Dakota.
The study deploys nine analytical modules spanning descriptive statistics, time series econometrics, panel regression, gravity models, machine learning, causal inference, and duration analysis.
The study uses data from 2002–2024.
North Dakota's migration profile is dominated by refugee resettlement rather than economic migration chains.
Location Quotients for Liberia exceed 40 in North Dakota.
Location Quotients for other West and East African origins exceed 20 in North Dakota.
North Dakota's international migration time series exhibits I(1) integration.
The coefficient of variation for North Dakota's international migration is 82.5%.
Annual migration flows to North Dakota can deviate from expectations by amounts approaching the mean itself.
Structural break analysis identifies significant regime shifts in 2020 associated with the COVID-19 pandemic (F = 16.01, p < 0.001).
Structural break analysis identifies significant regime shifts in 2021 associated with the COVID-19 pandemic.
Difference-in-differences estimation identifies a policy-associated divergence of approximately 75% in refugee arrivals from Travel Ban-affected countries (p = 0.032).
Aggregate time series analysis fails to detect the 75% divergence in refugee arrivals from Travel Ban-affected countries.
Pre-treatment trend divergence suggests the 75% estimate likely represents an upper bound on the causal effect of the Travel Ban.
In gravity model estimation, diaspora associations lose statistical significance when controlling for population mass.
The diaspora coefficient attenuates from 0.45 to 0.14 (p = 0.57) when controlling for population mass in gravity models.
Diaspora-linked allocation patterns remain modest in cross-sectional gravity model specifications.
Monte Carlo scenario projections extend through 2045.
The migration forecast for North Dakota is 9,056 persons.
The 95% prediction interval for the migration forecast spans 3,570 to 14,491 persons.
The prediction interval width represents a factor of 4.1.
The wide prediction interval characterizes the structural uncertainty inherent in small-state migration forecasting.
The wide prediction interval has direct implications for demographic planning.
Agencies must develop contingent capacity strategies rather than relying on misleadingly precise point forecasts.
The multi-method framework demonstrates that rigorous demographic analysis remains feasible even when small populations strain conventional asymptotic methods.
Rigorous demographic analysis for small populations requires careful attention to identification assumptions and uncertainty quantification.
This study offers three principal contributions to the migration forecasting literature.
This study provides the first comprehensive multi-method empirical analysis of international migration to a small U.S. state.
The nine-module analytical framework spans descriptive statistics, time series analysis, panel regression, gravity models, machine learning, causal inference, and duration analysis.
Rigorous demographic analysis remains feasible even when small populations and short time series strain conventional asymptotic methods.
The multi-method design explicitly trades depth within any single paradigm for robustness across paradigms.
The multi-method design generates convergent findings that warrant greater confidence than single-method analyses could support.
This study demonstrates novel applications of causal inference methods to state-level migration policy evaluation.
The difference-in-differences estimate identifies a policy-associated divergence of approximately 75% in refugee arrivals from Travel Ban-affected countries (p = 0.032).
Pre-treatment trend violations suggest the 75% divergence represents an upper bound on the causal effect rather than a point estimate.
A synthetic comparator provides descriptive benchmarking for North Dakota without causal interpretation.
A shift-share index establishes first-stage relevance linking refugee-driven shocks to state migration.
These causal inference methods extend the migration policy evaluation toolkit beyond the national-level and gateway-state analyses that dominate existing literature.
This study develops a rigorous framework for uncertainty quantification in long-range migration forecasts.
The scenario analysis distinguishes forecast uncertainty (parametric imprecision within a policy regime) from scenario uncertainty (unknowable future policy choices).
Monte Carlo simulation propagates parameter uncertainty through projection models to generate forecast distributions.
The study uses probability distributions rather than point estimates for migration projections.
The 95% prediction interval for 2045 migration spans a factor of 4.1.
The wide prediction interval honestly characterizes the structural uncertainty inherent in migration forecasting.
North Dakota's international migration is refugee-dominated.
North Dakota's international migration is policy-sensitive.
The Location Quotient analysis reveals extreme overrepresentation of African and Middle Eastern origins in North Dakota.
The overrepresentation of African and Middle Eastern origins is a product of federal resettlement decisions rather than economic migration chains.
Policy interventions affecting refugee source regions produce immediate and substantial effects on state-level migration flows.
Demographic planners must recognize policy dependence as a fundamental feature of the forecasting problem for refugee migration.
The coefficient of variation of small-state refugee migration is 82.5%.
Small-state migration exhibits random-walk baseline characteristics.
A dramatic structural break in refugee migration occurred in 2020.
Migration levels can shift by amounts approaching the mean itself due to high volatility.
The scenario range for North Dakota refugee migration extends from 2,517 to 19,318 migrants by 2045.
High volatility of small-state migration requires scenario-based planning rather than point forecasting.
The diaspora elasticity for North Dakota is 0.14.
North Dakota's diaspora elasticity of 0.14 is below estimates from gateway state and cross-national studies.
Refugee resettlement in North Dakota has not yet generated the self-reinforcing migration chains observed in more established immigrant communities.
North Dakota's refugee migration depends heavily on external policy rather than internal momentum.
Investments in community development may strengthen diaspora associations in North Dakota over time.
Extension of the analytical framework to other Great Plains states would assess whether North Dakota's patterns generalize across the region.
South Dakota, Nebraska, and Minnesota share demographic challenges and refugee resettlement participation with North Dakota.
Incorporation of county-level dynamics would illuminate the geographic distribution of migration within North Dakota.
Urban centers including Fargo and Grand Forks receive the majority of refugee arrivals in North Dakota.
Secondary migration from urban centers to smaller communities may follow different patterns than initial refugee arrivals.
County-level analysis could inform local planning and identify communities where service capacity constraints bind.
Integration with labor market outcomes would address whether international migration alleviates workforce shortages in rural regions.
Linking migration data to employment outcomes could quantify the economic contributions of immigrant populations.
Real-time forecasting with updated data would enable the scenario framework to evolve as new information becomes available.
The post-COVID recovery trajectory remains incompletely characterized given data limitations.
International migration to North Dakota is small in absolute terms.
International migration to North Dakota is volatile over time.
International migration to North Dakota is concentrated in humanitarian categories.
International migration to North Dakota is sensitive to federal policy decisions.
This study sought to provide a framework by combining methodological rigor with honest acknowledgment of forecasting limits.
The contribution of this study lies in characterizing uncertainty accurately rather than resolving it.
Accurate characterization of uncertainty enables demographic planners to develop robust strategies that perform reasonably across plausible futures.
Robust strategies that perform across plausible futures are preferable to optimizing for misleadingly precise point forecasts.
The analysis employs a multi-method design that reflects both the complexity of international migration dynamics and the inferential challenges posed by small-sample settings.

Four methodological traditions are employed: descriptive methods establish baseline patterns; time series techniques characterize dynamic properties; regression approaches quantify relationships; and causal inference methods identify policy effects.

The multi-method approach enables triangulation across analytical frameworks, enhancing confidence in findings that emerge consistently while flagging conclusions dependent on particular modeling assumptions.
The analysis is organized into a nine-module analytical pipeline.
Modules 1-6 provide descriptive diagnostics, baseline time-series structure, and predictive covariates.
Module 7 offers causal evidence of policy sensitivity, which informs the narrative interpretation of scenarios but does not replace the forecast target.
Module 8 translates refugee wave persistence into a forecasting adjustment.
Module 9 integrates all inputs into scenario paths and Monte Carlo uncertainty.
The forecast target (estimand) is North Dakota's annual net international migration in year t, denoted Yt, measured as the PEP international migration component of change.
Yt is measured in persons, on a net basis.
The forecasting goal is to characterize the predictive distribution of Yt+h for horizons 2025-2045, conditional on information available through year t.
DHS LPR admissions, RPC refugee arrivals, and ACS foreign-born stock estimates are auxiliary data sources used to characterize and partially decompose international migration.
Auxiliary data sources are used to construct predictors such as diaspora measures and origin-composition features.
PEP estimates are reported on an estimate-year basis, while DHS and RPC series are reported in fiscal years and ACS estimates in survey years.
When fiscal-year series are used as predictors for PEP-year outcomes, they are aligned using an overlap-weighted crosswalk.
PEP international migration is a net component of population accounting, while DHS and RPC series are gross inflows.
Census PEP measures state net international migration component of population change and is the primary forecast target.
PEP estimates are model-based estimates that are composite of multiple international channels and are subject to revision.
The 2020 PEP estimate reflects both true disruption and potential measurement artifacts.
RPC refugee arrivals measure refugee arrivals by nationality and state of initial placement.
Initial refugee placement does not equal final residence due to secondary migration.
RPC data contain many zeros at the state by nationality level.
The Census Bureau's PEP provides annual estimates of population and components of change for states and counties.
The analysis employs vintage 2024 estimates covering 2010-2024, decomposing annual population change into births, deaths, domestic migration, and international migration.
The international migration component comprises the net flow of foreign-born individuals plus the net movement of native-born citizens and military personnel abroad.
For subnational units, the Census Bureau allocates national international migration estimates to states using ACS data on recent movers and foreign-born population distributions.
The international migration variable aggregates heterogeneous streams (LPRs, refugees, temporary workers, unauthorized migrants) into a single measure.
The allocation methodology may introduce smoothing artifacts at the state level.
DHS publishes annual statistics on LPR admissions by state of intended residence and country of birth.
LPR data provide granular information on country-of-origin composition, enabling gravity model estimation and concentration analysis.
LPR counts derive from visa issuance records and represent actual admissions rather than estimates.
DHS data exclude non-LPR categories such as refugees, asylees, and temporary workers.
The ACS provides annual estimates of foreign-born population by place of birth for states and metropolitan areas.
The analysis employs five-year ACS estimates from 2009-2023, using detailed country-of-birth tabulations.
For small populations such as foreign-born from specific countries residing in North Dakota, coefficients of variation can exceed 30%.
The analysis addresses sampling uncertainty by focusing on origin groups with sufficient sample sizes and aggregating to regional categories where country-level estimates prove unreliable.
The Refugee Processing Center maintains comprehensive records of refugee arrivals by state of initial resettlement and nationality.
The analysis employs refugee arrival data spanning fiscal years 2002-2020, providing the longest time series among the data sources.
North Dakota has a significant refugee population, which drives much of the geographic concentration observed in other data sources.
Refugee arrival data offer precise counts (not estimates) of a well-defined population admitted through federal resettlement programs.
Refugee data are truncated at fiscal year 2020, precluding analysis of pandemic recovery.
Summary statistics include means, standard deviations, coefficients of variation, skewness, and kurtosis.
The coefficient of variation is defined as the ratio of standard deviation to mean.
The coefficient of variation provides a scale-invariant measure of volatility suitable for comparing series of different magnitudes.
The analysis employs the Hodrick-Prescott filter to decompose observed migration flows into trend and cyclical components.
Following Ravn and Uhlig (2002), the analysis sets lambda = 6.25 for annual data.
Geographic concentration analysis employs the Herfindahl-Hirschman Index and Location Quotients.
HHI values below 1,500 indicate unconcentrated distributions.
HHI values between 1,500 and 2,500 indicate moderate concentration.
HHI values above 2,500 indicate high concentration.
Location Quotients measure the degree to which North Dakota's immigrant composition deviates from national patterns.
Location quotients exceeding unity indicate overrepresentation of an origin group in North Dakota relative to the nation.
Time series analysis proceeds through four stages: unit root testing, ARIMA model specification, structural break detection, and VAR for multivariate dynamics.
Stationarity assessment employs ADF and PP tests alongside KPSS to triangulate integration properties.
The KPSS test has a null hypothesis of stationarity.
Lag length is selected by the Akaike Information Criterion.
The Phillips-Perron test provides a nonparametric alternative that corrects for serial correlation without augmenting the regression.
Break-robust Zivot-Andrews tests are reported as sensitivity checks.
For series exhibiting unit roots, the analysis fits ARIMA models of order (p, d, q).
The analysis employs the Ljung-Box portmanteau test for residual autocorrelation.
Structural break analysis employs three complementary approaches.
The Chow test evaluates whether regression parameters differ across known candidate break points.
The CUSUM test detects parameter instability through cumulative sums of recursive residuals.
For endogenous break detection, the analysis employs the Bai and Perron (1998) procedure.
Given the short time series (n = 15), the analysis sets the minimum segment length to 2 years.
The analysis estimates a VAR to examine dynamic interdependencies between North Dakota and national migration flows.
Granger causality tests evaluate directional predictive relationships in the VAR model.
Forecast error variance decomposition quantifies the contribution of each variable to forecast uncertainty.
Panel data analysis employs state-year observations spanning 51 states over 15 years (2010-2024), yielding 765 observations.
In the fixed effects model, state-specific intercepts absorb time-invariant heterogeneity.
The random effects model treats state-specific intercepts as random draws from a population distribution.
Model selection between fixed and random effects employs the Hausman test.
Standard errors are clustered at the state level to account for within-state serial correlation.
Cross-sectional allocation models quantify how LPR admissions are distributed across state-origin pairs as a function of diaspora stocks and destination characteristics.
The analysis estimates specifications using the Poisson pseudo-maximum likelihood (PPML) estimator.
PPML addresses heteroskedasticity-induced bias and the inability to accommodate zero flows that affect log-linear OLS.
Diaspora stocks and migration flows are jointly determined.
The analysis frames diaspora elasticity coefficients as predictive associations rather than causal effects.
Machine learning methods complement traditional regression by providing flexible functional forms and systematic variable selection.
The analysis employs three ML techniques: Elastic Net regularization, Random Forest regression, and K-means clustering.
Elastic Net combines L1 (Lasso) and L2 (Ridge) penalties.
Random Forest aggregates predictions from an ensemble of decision trees trained on bootstrap samples with random feature subsets.
Feature importance is measured by permutation importance: the decrease in out-of-bag prediction accuracy when feature values are shuffled.
K-means clustering partitions states into groups exhibiting similar migration profiles.
Optimal cluster count K is selected by the silhouette criterion.
Causal inference methods estimate the effects of the 2017 Travel Ban and the 2020 COVID-19 pandemic on international migration flows.
Identification relies on nationality-level difference-in-differences and a state-level interrupted time series.
The Travel Ban analysis employs a DiD design comparing refugee arrivals from affected countries (Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria, Yemen) to arrivals from unaffected countries.
In the DiD estimating equation, the coefficient delta identifies the average treatment effect on the treated (ATT).
Identification requires the parallel trends assumption: absent the Travel Ban, affected and unaffected countries would have exhibited similar trends.
The analysis evaluates parallel trends through pre-treatment trend tests and graphical inspection.
With only seven treated nationalities, conventional cluster-robust inference may be unreliable.
Clustered standard errors are supplemented with wild cluster bootstrap and randomization inference.
Both wild cluster bootstrap and randomization inference provide finite-sample valid inference without relying on asymptotic cluster count assumptions.
The COVID-19 analysis uses a state-level interrupted time series with state fixed effects.
Because the Travel Ban is a national shock, donor states are not untreated.
A synthetic comparator is used only as a descriptive benchmark, not for causal inference.
A shift-share (Bartik) index is constructed to assess the predictive relevance of refugee-driven shocks for state-level migration.
The shift-share index combines national-level shifts in immigration by origin country with state-level shares reflecting historical settlement patterns.
First-stage F-statistics assess instrument strength, with values exceeding 10 indicating adequate relevance.
Duration analysis examines the lifecycle of migration waves-sustained periods of elevated arrivals from specific origin countries.
A wave is defined as a period during which arrivals from a nationality exceed 150% of baseline for two or more consecutive years.
The Kaplan-Meier estimator provides nonparametric estimates of the survival function.
The log-rank test evaluates whether survival curves differ across strata.
The Cox proportional hazards model relates the hazard rate to covariates.
Hazard ratios below unity indicate factors prolonging waves; above unity indicate factors accelerating termination.
The proportional hazards assumption is evaluated through Schoenfeld residual tests.
Model discrimination is assessed by the concordance index (C-statistic).
Some modules provide direct forecasting inputs while others provide contextual evidence that informs scenario interpretation.
The VAR model serves primarily as an auxiliary analysis and is not used for standalone long-horizon forecasting.
ML methods provide feature importance rankings and state clustering for comparative context but do not directly parameterize scenario trajectories.
Scenario analysis translates analytical findings into forward-looking projections while explicitly characterizing uncertainty.
The analysis develops four policy-indexed scenarios spanning the range of plausible future trajectories.
The CBO Full scenario uses ARIMA point forecasts scaled by 1.1 for 2025-2029, compounding at 8% annually from 2030 onward.
The Moderate scenario uses ARIMA point forecasts for 2025-2029 with a dampened trend through 2045.
The Pre-2020 Trend scenario anchors at the 2019 level and extrapolates the 2010-2019 slope.
The Zero scenario assumes complete cessation of international migration.
Monte Carlo simulation propagates uncertainty through projection models by sampling from estimated parameter distributions.
The Monte Carlo procedure draws 1,000 realizations of model parameters.
The 50% prediction interval spans the 25th to 75th percentiles.
The 95% prediction interval spans the 2.5th to 97.5th percentiles.
Model averaging combines forecasts from multiple specifications using AIC-derived weights.
All analyses were conducted in Python 3.11.
Time series analysis employed statsmodels for ARIMA, VAR, and unit root tests.
Panel data models were estimated using linearmodels.
Machine learning methods used scikit-learn for Elastic Net, Random Forest, and clustering.
Survival analysis employed the lifelines package for Kaplan-Meier estimation and Cox regression.
Structural break detection used the ruptures package.
Replication code and data are available in the supplementary materials.
North Dakota's net international migration averaged 1,796 persons annually (SE = 383) over the 2010-2024 observation period.
North Dakota's net international migration had a coefficient of variation of 82.5%.
National net international migration exhibited a coefficient of variation of 73.5%.
State-level flows experience amplified fluctuation relative to aggregate national trends.
The distribution of annual international migration to North Dakota exhibits positive skewness (1.10).
The Shapiro-Wilk test marginally fails to reject normality (W = 0.886, p = 0.058).
No observations qualify as extreme outliers under the interquartile range criterion.
The 2020 value of 30 migrants represents a dramatic departure from typical levels.
Hodrick-Prescott filter decomposition reveals a U-shaped trend in North Dakota's share of national international migration.
The Herfindahl-Hirschman Index for country-of-origin composition is 1,162 based on FY 2023 LPR admissions.
North Dakota's immigrant origins are classified as unconcentrated at the country level (HHI < 1,500).
The regional-level HHI reaches 3,712, placing North Dakota in the highly concentrated category.
Asia accounts for 52.5% of LPR admissions to North Dakota.
Africa accounts for 27.9% of LPR admissions to North Dakota.
Liberia exhibits the highest Location Quotient (LQ = 40.83).
Ivory Coast has an LQ of 26.19.
Somalia has an LQ of 22.42.
Tanzania has an LQ of 15.13.
North Dakota international migration does not reject the unit root null in levels (p = 0.556) but rejects after first differencing (p = 0.002), consistent with I(1) behavior.
National international migration rejects the unit root null in levels (p = 0.002), consistent with I(0) behavior.
ARIMA model selection via AIC identifies ARIMA(0,1,0) as the baseline specification.
The Ljung-Box portmanteau test finds no significant residual autocorrelation through lag 5 (Q = 4.12, p = 0.404).
Residuals pass the Shapiro-Wilk normality test (W = 0.968, p = 0.820).
The 2029 forecast of 5,126 migrants carries a 95% prediction interval of [212, 10,040].
The driver regression using contemporaneous U.S. migration achieves MASE = 0.27.
No feasible model significantly outperforms the random walk.
The 2020 COVID-19 pandemic represents a highly significant structural break (F = 16.01, p < 0.001).
Mean international migration to North Dakota increased from 1,378 pre-2020 to 2,633 post-2020, a 91.1% increase.
The 2017 Travel Ban does not represent a significant structural break at aggregate level (F = 1.29, p = 0.314).
The 2021 post-COVID recovery represents a significant structural break (F = 10.28, p = 0.003) with a 161.6% regime shift.
The Bai-Perron procedure identifies zero breaks under the BIC criterion.
The panel estimation sample comprises 765 state-year observations (51 states x 15 years).
The Hausman test supports random effects as the preferred specification (H = 7.18e-31, p = 1.000).
The Breusch-Pagan LM test strongly rejects pooled OLS (chi-sq = 1,502, p < 0.001).
Florida exhibits the largest positive state fixed effect (+125,526 relative to grand mean).
North Dakota's fixed effect of -18,022 places it near the bottom of the distribution.
Mean international migration in 2020 was 390 compared to 21,206 in other years, a 98.2% reduction.
The simple diaspora specification yields an association of 0.448 (SE = 0.104, p < 0.001).
With two-way clustered SEs, the diaspora association attenuates to 0.140 (SE = 0.248, p = 0.57).
State foreign-born totals remain the dominant predictor (elasticity = 0.792, SE = 0.212, p < 0.001).
The full model explains 40% of deviance (pseudo-R-sq = 0.399).
The estimated ATT for the Travel Ban is -1.384 on the log scale (t = -2.14, p = 0.032).
The ATT corresponds to a policy-associated divergence of 74.9% in refugee arrivals from affected countries.
The event study's joint pre-treatment test rejects parallel trends over the full pre-period (F = 4.31, p < 0.001).
Pre-treatment trend divergence suggests the 75% estimate represents an upper bound on the causal effect.
Wild cluster bootstrap yields p = 0.077 for the full pre-period specification.
Randomization inference yields p = 0.058 for the full pre-period specification.
Restricting the pre-period to 2013-2017 improves the pre-trend diagnostic (F = 0.76, p = 0.553).
The ATT with restricted pre-period increases to -1.983 (SE = 0.506), corresponding to -86%.
Bootstrap and randomization inference confirm significance at the 1% level (p = 0.003 and p = 0.004).
The ITS level shift coefficient indicates migration dropped by 19,503 persons after COVID onset (t = -4.28, p < 0.001).
The trend change coefficient of +14,113 reflects the steep post-pandemic rebound slope during 2021-2024.
The synthetic control weights emphasize Wyoming (41.9%), Vermont (24.5%), Rhode Island (20.1%), and Washington (8.3%).
The first-stage F-statistic of 39.95 exceeds the conventional threshold of 10, supporting instrument relevance.
Wave identification identifies 940 waves across 56 nationalities and 48 states in 2002-2020 refugee data.
Kaplan-Meier estimation yields a median wave duration of 3.0 years (mean = 3.54 years).
51.6% of waves survive past year 2, 31.8% past year 3, 21.6% past year 4, and 6.2% past year 10.
The log-rank test rejects equality of survival curves across intensity quartiles (chi-sq = 278.7, p < 10^-60).
African waves have a mean duration of 3.99 years; Middle Eastern 4.14; Asian 4.28; European 2.40; Americas 2.25.
For log intensity, the hazard ratio is 0.412 (p < 0.001), indicating 59% lower hazard of termination.
The Cox model achieves a concordance index of 0.769.
The CBO Full scenario projects 19,318 persons by 2045.
The Moderate scenario yields 7,048 persons by 2045.
The Pre-2020 Trend scenario projects 2,517 persons by 2045.
The median 2045 Monte Carlo projection is 9,056 persons with 95% PI [3,570, 14,491].
The 95% prediction interval spans a factor of 4.1.
Elastic Net regularization achieves R2_CV = 0.60 and identifies three non-zero predictors.
Random Forest achieves R2_CV = 0.94 and confirms log population dominates feature importance (93%).
K-means clustering (K = 2; silhouette = 0.64) places North Dakota in the larger cluster with 52 states.
The multi-method analysis yielded convergent findings across nine analytical modules.
The multi-method analysis revealed the inherent limits of prediction in this domain.
Country-level diversity masks regional concentration in North Dakota's immigration profile.
Asia and Africa together comprise over 80% of legal permanent resident flows to North Dakota.
Regional-level HHI has increased substantially from approximately 2,600 in the early 2010s to over 5,200 by 2022-2023.
North Dakota's migration profile is becoming more distinctive over time, diverging further from the national pattern.
Under the random-walk baseline, the best forecast of future migration equals the most recent observation.
The random-walk characterization implies limited mean reversion within the sample.
The 2017 Travel Ban left no detectable trace in aggregate state-level data despite documented effects on refugee flows.
The divergence between aggregate and composition-specific effects illustrates how structural instability can manifest asymmetrically across analytical scales.
The 75% effect magnitude exceeds what aggregate analysis could detect because effects concentrated on specific nationalities.
The parallel trends assumption essential for causal identification in DiD is not satisfied over the full pre-treatment period.
Nationality-level panel methods can identify compositional effects that aggregate time series approaches miss.
The rapid post-COVID recovery suggests immigration systems can bounce back from acute shocks more rapidly than the random-walk baseline might imply.
The wide forecast range reflects multiple uncertainty sources: migration volatility (CV = 82.5%), structural instability, and policy unpredictability.
The scenario framework distinguishes between forecast uncertainty and scenario uncertainty.
The diaspora association of 0.140 falls below estimates reported in prior cross-national studies.
Beine et al. (2011) estimate diaspora elasticities ranging from 0.4 to 0.7.
North Dakota's small absolute foreign-born population may generate insufficient network density to support chain migration mechanisms.
Destination foreign-born totals dominate migration allocation with an elasticity of 0.792.
Higher-intensity waves persist substantially longer, with median duration of 4 years for Q4 versus 2 years for Q1.
Refugee resettlement operates in episodic surges rather than continuous streams.
African and Asian waves outlast European and American waves, with mean duration of 4+ years versus approximately 2 years.
Traditional planning models premised on smooth population growth require substantial adaptation for migration settings with high volatility.
The 75% policy-associated divergence underscores how dependent state-level migration is on federal policy decisions outside state control.
North Dakota receives disproportionate shares of migrants from countries frequently subject to policy intervention.
This policy exposure creates planning risks that states with more diversified migration portfolios face to a lesser degree.
The modest diaspora association (0.140) suggests North Dakota's refugee communities have not yet generated self-reinforcing migration chains.
Investments in community development may strengthen diaspora associations over time.
For Great Plains states facing persistent labor shortages, international migration represents a critical workforce pipeline.
Higher-intensity immigration waves persist longer, suggesting initial resettlement investments may yield extended returns.
The time series analysis operates with only 15 annual observations (2010-2024), constraining power of statistical tests.
The refugee arrival data end in fiscal year 2020, precluding examination of post-COVID recovery patterns.
The synthetic comparator is descriptive rather than causal because the Travel Ban is a national shock.
Findings from a single small state may not generalize to other contexts.
The methodological framework, rather than specific parameter estimates, represents the more transferable contribution.
The BIC criterion detects 0 breaks (penalty on parameters dominates).
The AIC criterion detects 1 break at 2020 (F = 14.23, p < 0.001).
The sequential procedure detects 2 breaks at 2017 and 2020 (marginal significance at 2017).
Cross-sectional allocation models omit origin-destination distance because variation in distance from a given origin country to different U.S. states is minimal.
The divergence between criteria reflects the tension between model fit and parsimony in short time series.
The Year 2020 coefficient is -20,816 (p < 0.001) in the pooled OLS panel regression.
The pooled OLS model achieves R-squared of 0.312.
The fixed effects model achieves overall R-squared of 0.298.
The random effects model achieves overall R-squared of 0.308.
Standard errors are clustered at the state level for FE and RE specifications.
The Log(Diaspora Stock) coefficient is 0.448 (p < 0.001) in the simple PPML specification.
The Log(State Foreign-Born Total) coefficient is 0.792 (p < 0.001) in the full PPML specification.
The full PPML specification with destination fixed effects achieves pseudo R-squared of 0.413.
The Affected x Post coefficient for the Travel Ban is -1.384 (p < 0.05) in the full difference-in-differences specification.
The pre-trend test p-value is 0.334 in the full difference-in-differences specification, supporting the parallel trends assumption.
The ADF test on levels with constant only yields statistic -1.453 (p = 0.556), failing to reject the unit root null.
The ADF test on first-differenced series yields statistic -3.843 (p = 0.002), rejecting the unit root null.
The Zivot-Andrews test with break in intercept identifies a break at 2021 but fails to reject the unit root (statistic -3.049, p = 0.897).
Lag order selection across multiple criteria (AIC, BIC, HQIC, FPE) uniformly favors VAR(1).
The VAR(1) model achieves R-squared of 0.58 for the ND equation and R-squared of 0.60 for the US equation.
No individual VAR(1) coefficient achieves statistical significance at the 5% level, reflecting the very short sample (n = 14 after differencing).
The US to ND Granger causality chi-squared test marginally rejects the null (chi-squared = 4.10, p = 0.043), but the F-test does not (F = 3.22, p = 0.100).
The ND to US Granger causality tests fail to reject the null (p > 0.96), as expected given ND's negligible share of national migration.
By period 10, approximately 82% of ND forecast error variance is attributable to ND's own shocks, with 18% attributable to US shocks.

The Engle-Granger two-step procedure suggests cointegration (ADF on residuals: -4.48, p < 0.001), but the Johansen trace test does not reject zero cointegrating relations at the 5% level (trace = 7.18, critical value = 15.49).
The VAR is not used for standalone long-horizon forecasting because it requires future values of US international migration, which is unavailable at forecast time.
The VECM model confirms the contemporaneous ND-US correlation (cointegrating relationship) and provides variance decomposition context for interpreting scenario uncertainty.
Alternative covariance estimators highlight the inflation of uncertainty under clustered inference.
The diaspora coefficient point estimate is 0.140 under the model-based Poisson MLE estimator with SE of 0.002.
The diaspora coefficient point estimate is 0.140 under the HC1 robust estimator with SE of 0.176.
The diaspora coefficient point estimate is 0.140 under the clustered by state estimator with SE of 0.113.
The diaspora coefficient point estimate is 0.140 under the clustered by origin estimator with SE of 0.282.
The diaspora coefficient point estimate is 0.140 under the two-way clustered (state x origin) estimator with SE of 0.248.
The point estimate is stable across covariance estimators, but clustered SEs are substantially larger than model-based SEs.
Two-way clustered inference is reported in the main text.
The interaction between Affected and a linear pre-treatment trend yields 0.087 (t = 0.97, p = 0.334).
The pre-treatment trend test fails to reject parallel trends.
Placebo tests shifting the treatment date to 2015 or 2016 were conducted in the prior HC3 specification.
Figure 7 shows negative post-treatment coefficients in 2018-2019.
The joint pre-treatment test rejects parallel trends when the full pre-period is included (p < 0.001), indicating longer-run divergence.
For CBO Full scenario, 2025-2029 projections use 10% above the ARIMA point forecasts, and from 2030 onward values compound at 8% annually.
For Pre-2020 Trend scenario, the series is anchored at the 2019 value (y2019 = 634) with a slope estimated from 2010-2019 (beta = 72.43 per year).
For Moderate scenario, 2025-2029 uses ARIMA point forecasts directly, and from 2030 onward the trend is dampened to 50% of the averaged robust trend estimate.
For Zero scenario, net international migration is set to zero for all years.

The Monte Carlo simulation in Module 9 combines two sources of stochastic variation: ARIMA baseline uncertainty from the estimated random-walk process, and wave duration draws from the Cox proportional hazards model (Module 8).
A potential concern is double-counting of refugee-driven volatility, since the ARIMA model is trained on the full PEPnet migration series which includes historical refugee arrivals.
The wave simulation does not add independent refugee variance; rather, it modulates the timing and persistence of above-baseline arrivals conditional on an active wave being detected.
The ARIMA baseline captures the unconditional mean and variance of the PEP series, which reflects average historical refugee influence.

The Cox-based wave simulation draws wave durations conditional on observed wave characteristics (intensity, age, origin region) and applies a lifecycle shape function (initiation to peak to decline) to allocate excess arrivals over time.
Wave contributions are defined as excess arrivals above the origin-specific baseline, not as additive draws independent of the ARIMA process.
Because the ARIMA was not trained on a refugee-stripped series, some overlap between baseline variance and wave-induced variance may remain.
Separating refugee from non-refugee components in PEP data is infeasible without auxiliary assumptions.
The Monte Carlo prediction intervals should be interpreted as conservative (potentially inflated) rather than calibrated probability statements.
The 95% prediction interval spans a factor of 4.1 by 2045.
The Census Bureau Population Estimates Program data source uses vintage 2024.
Census Population Estimates Program coverage is 2010-2024 annual estimates.
Census Population Estimates Program geographic scope is 50 states plus District of Columbia.
DHS LPR Statistics coverage is Fiscal Year 2023.
DHS LPR Statistics geographic scope is state of intended residence by country of birth.
American Community Survey vintage is 5-year estimates, 2009-2023.
Refugee Processing Center data coverage is Fiscal Years 2002-2020.
Refugee Processing Center data geographic scope is state of initial resettlement by nationality.
Figure 10 displays the distribution of PEPnet international migration across U.S. states, highlighting North Dakota's position in the lower tail.
Figure 11 presents residual diagnostic plots for the ARIMA(0,1,0) specification.
Figure 12 displays Schoenfeld residual plots for evaluating the proportional hazards assumption in the Cox regression model.
North Dakota has mean annual international migration of 1,796.
The median mean annual international migration across states is 7,942.
North Dakota ranks 6/51 among states by migration volume.
The distribution of state migration levels is highly right-skewed, with California, Texas, Florida, and New York comprising the upper tail.
Travel Ban affected countries are Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria, and Yemen.
ARIMA(0,1,0) residual time series shows no apparent pattern.
Shapiro-Wilk test for ARIMA residuals yields W = 0.968, p = 0.820, failing to reject normality.
Residual ACF has all lags within 95% confidence bounds, confirming absence of serial correlation.
Global test for proportional hazards fails to reject proportional hazards (chi-squared = 8.34, df = 3, p = 0.214).
Flat trends in Schoenfeld residuals indicate satisfaction of the proportional hazards assumption.
